Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a Biopotential Measurement System

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Research Objectives and Approaches: The objective of this research is to bridge engineering and natural sciences in an inter-disciplinary collaboration, which will enhance course instruction and research projects across disciplines. The approach is to acquire a state-of-art biopotential instrumentation system that allows the PIs to enhance their collaboration in more advanced research projects with students.

Intellectual Merit: The intellectual merit of the proposal is centered on enhancing a facility that will foster the interaction between the faculty and students in science and engineering to plan and conduct research. This interaction will allow its members to work as a team of scientists and engineers across disciplines, and to interpret and communicate research findings in both peer-reviewed journal publications and at national conferences.

Broader Impacts: The broader impacts will be to effectively integrate education and research; enhance scientific and technical understanding, and engage in research that can benefit society. The outcome of this research is aimed at developing new devices and/or new treatments to improve the quality of life of individuals suffering from neurological disorders. This collaboration is being conducted by under-represented minorities at different stages of professional development, who have demonstrated a track record of engaging under-represented minority students in research in the natural sciences and engineering. This equipment will be utilized to continue improving the research projects from their successful collaborations and allow students to conduct research and independent study projects. Through a data-sharing plan, peer-institutions will be able to access the data collected with this equipment for other projects.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit:  The biopotential instrument purchased through this grant provides research opportunities for faculty in this undergraduate institution which, in turn, generates opportunities for the undergraduates to participate in advanced research either of their own design or as part of the faculty members’ research team. With the biopotential measurement instrumentation, the PI, Co-PIs, and their students are able to conduct research projects on brain-computer interface, human behavior studies, wearable health monitoring system development, and artificial neural network design.

Over the last three years, the instrument has supported seven research projects, five student honors theses, and two courses. Results from these projects were presented in 6 presentations on Lafayette campus and 11 conference presentations. We are in the process to assemble the results into three journal articles to be submitted in the next 6 months.

 

Broader Impact:  The broader impact of this project entails the training of future engineers and scientists for research applied to health problems. The instrument was used by seventeen undergraduate students to conduct their research projects with the PI and the co-PIs for the last three years. These students included eight female students, four internatiuonal students, and one student from an underrepresented group.

Our research team, consisting of engineers, neuroscientists, and psychologists, is truely interdiscipline. The demands from science fields provide engineers the opportunites to improve existing designs and/or create new ones that can better serve for the needs. On the other hand, the new designs from engineering disciplines also allow scientists exploring new knowledge that were not possible for the limitations of the old technologies. Our students learned the importance of interdisciplinary work in order to solve important questions for all the disciplines involved. For example, the determination of sensorimotor coordination and development is an important topic that will require creative
approaches in neuroscience. For art, learning the neural and cognitive processes involved in learning to draw from observation can
facilitate the modification of pedagogical approaches.

The results from the brain-computer interface research projects could lead to new devices to improve patients’ quality of lives as well as new treatments for patients who suffer from neurological or mental illness. In addition, better understand of human brain functions also leads to improvement in technologies, such as robotics, cybernetics, and computers.
